page.title: 17MITCHELDEAN NATURE RESERVES
page.content: There are two nature reserves in the Mitcheldean area, quite different in character from each other. A layer of clay, thought by geologists to have been deposited during the Ice Age on the plateau-like summit of Plump Hill has produced some natural ponds with surrounding "wetland", due to its impervious character. This is an important refuge for bog plants. Nearer Mitcheldean is the abandoned Stenders quarry, with both Carboniferous and Devonian rocks exposed due to the steep angle of dip. Both formations contain fossils, and there are wild flowers of both the limestone and sandstone rocks, while the quarry is also a refuge for badgers, foxes and ravens.
